datafield.subfield: Arthur Schwartz was an American composer and film producer. He is particularly known for his songwriting partnership with lyricist Howard Dietz. The collection, which documents his life and career, includes music manuscripts, sketches and lyric sheets, correspondence, photographs, scripts, clippings, publicity materials, financial and legal documents, writings, and awards.
American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

titlestmt.author: Processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2012

change.item: Nancy Seeger corrected Schwartz's birth date and made another correction.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Arthur Schwartz was an American composer and film producer. He is particularly known for his songwriting partnership with lyricist Howard Dietz. The collection, which documents his life and career, includes music manuscripts, sketches and lyric sheets, correspondence, photographs, scripts, clippings, publicity materials, financial and legal documents, writings, and awards.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: People
controlaccess.persname: Schwartz, Arthur, 1900-1984. Band wagon. Dancing in the dark.

controlaccess.head: Organizations
controlaccess.corpname: American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Between 1955 and 1965, Arthur Schwartz deposited and converted to gift music manuscripts for The Band Wagon, Jennie, and for the song "Something to Remember You By." Paul Schwartz donated the remaining, largest portion of the collection in 2001.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Arthur Schwartz Papers were processed by William Robin, Gina Bombola, Christopher Bowen, and Christopher Hartten in 2012. Christopher Hartten coded the finding aid for EAD format in 2012.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Sound recordings from the Arthur Schwartz Papers have been transferred to the Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division. An inventory of this material is available in the Music Division's collection file.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Original orchestrations and other scores for Flying Colors and The Band Wagon are found in the Music Division's Warner-Chappell Collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Materials from the Arthur Schwartz Papers are governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Arthur Schwartz Papers are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Music Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Arthur Schwartz Papers, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

Served on Dramatist Guild governing board
Lived in England but spent more time in the U.S. over the last three years

chronitem.event: Dancing in the Dark, a retrospective of Schwartz songs, performed at the Manhattan Theater Club
Inducted into the American Theatre Hall of Fame
Received ASCAP Foundation Richard Rodgers Award for lifetime achievement in the musical theater
Died Kintnersville, Pennsylvania

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Arthur Schwartz Papers span the years 1900-1983 with the bulk of the materials dating from 1931 to 1983. The collection includes music manuscripts, lyric sheets, scripts, correspondence, publicity materials, photographs, business papers, and other items that document Schwartz's life and career. The materials provide evidence for his musical growth and highlight the popularity of his songs, such as "Dancing in the Dark." The collection includes materials from the numerous musicals, revues, films, radio programs, and television series that Schwartz worked on. It also covers other aspects of Schwartz's career, including his contributions to ASCAP and the League of New York Theaters. In addition, scripts by George S. Kaufman, and Dorothy and Herbert Fields, as well as hundreds of lyric sheets by Howard Dietz, offer insights into the cultural history of American theater in the 20th century.

The Music series consists of manuscript and published scores, sketches, and lyric sheets for Schwartz's Broadway musicals, revues, films, and television and radio series, including The Band Wagon, The Gay Life, Inside U.S.A., The Gibson Family, and A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, as well as numerous unfinished projects. Many shows include unused or cut songs. Of particular interest are materials for the hit song, "Dancing in the Dark", one of the few titles in the collection to boast a complete set of scores and instrumental parts. Manuscript materials and annotations are mostly in Schwartz's hand.

Non-music materials associated with productions can be found in the Project Files series which is arranged alphabetically by project or show title. These contain scripts, miscellaneous lyric sheets, clippings, publicity materials, correspondence, financial and legal documents, photographs, and other items related to Schwartz's projects for which he composed music, acted as producer, or was otherwise involved. Several projects, most notably Jennie, feature substantial script revisions that span multiple boxes. Also included are a variety of scripts by George S. Kaufman, Sidney Sheldon, Herman Wouk, Herbert and Dorothy Fields, and other playwrights and screenwriters who collaborated with Schwartz on various projects.

The Correspondence series contains personal and professional letters to and from family members, collaborators, and other show business luminaries. Notable personalities include Howard Dietz, Dorothy Fields, Irving Berlin, Oscar Hammerstein II, and Richard Rodgers. In addition, the series contains Schwartz's communications with ASCAP, the American Guild of Authors and Composers, and other performing arts organizations. Photographs of Schwartz in the Photographs series date chiefly from the 1940s-1950s, although very few have descriptive captions of any kind. Most are professional portraits and shots of Schwartz at rehearsals or recording sessions. Photographs pertaining to stage or film productions are located within their corresponding project files.

The remaining collection items are consolidated into the Biographical Materials series. These include awards, published and unpublished writings, notebooks, business papers, legal documents, publicity materials, and other items. Writings consist mostly of interviews with Schwartz, short pieces about Schwartz's own music and that of other composers, writings by his son, Jonathan Schwartz, and miscellaneous essays and autobiographical texts. The business papers contain materials related to ASCAP, a handful of Schwartz's tax returns, contracts and legal documents, business correspondence, royalties, and other materials. Most intriguing, however, are fifteen notebooks featuring a variety of contents: drafts of correspondence and lyrics, musical sketches, and miscellaneous notes related to Schwartz's professional engagements. Additional biographical materials include clippings about Schwartz and articles about members of his family, lyricist Howard Dietz, the League of New York Theaters, and other topics.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Arthur Schwartz Papers
arrangement.p: The Arthur Schwartz Papers are organized in six series:

scopecontent.p: Holograph and copyist manuscript scores, sketches, publisher proofs, sheet music, instrumental parts, and lyric sheets related to Schwartz's stage productions and his other song-writing projects. Only a handful of titles have instrumental part sets, the most notable being "Dancing in the Dark." Additional lyric sheets and materials for titles not musically represented here are located within the "Project Files" series.

Chiefly scores, sketches, and lyric sheets for Broadway musicals and Hollywood films for which Schwartz contributed one or more selections. Many of these are holographs or bear annotations in Schwartz's hand. The term "sheet music" explicitly indicates titles for which published scores are the only materials present.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title of project and by song title therein.

note.p: Incidental music

scopecontent.p: Chiefly manuscript piano-vocal scores and sketches for songs not affiliated with stage productions. Among the titles are several commercials, a promotional song for Melody magazine, and a fight song written for New York University. Unless otherwise noted, all lyrics are by Howard Dietz or unknown lyricists.
